abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: Interactions of anaerobic gut bacteria with the intestinal mucosa have been poorly studied due to challenges in culturing anaerobes with the oxygen-requiring gut epithelium. Gut colonization by the anaerobic pathogen Clostridium difficile, a leading cause of hospital-acquired diarrhea, is a key determinant of disease outcome. However, precise mechanisms of mucosal attachment and spread remain unclear. Here, using human gut cells co-cultured within controlled dual environment chambers, we describe the dynamics of C. difficile infection. We demonstrate that C. difficile adheres and multiplies as micro-communities when grown on a mucin-producing Caco-2/HT29-MTX gut epithelial cell layer. Prolonged infection causes redistribution of actin and loss of epithelial integrity, accompanied by production of C. difficile spores, and interestingly C. difficile filamentation, a potentially new mechanism of C. difficile persistence. Intriguingly, we find that even in the absence of major C. difficile toxins, the bacterium is able to disrupt epithelial barrier function. To examine C. difficile-commensal interactions, we co-cultured C. difficile with the anaerobic gut commensal Bacteroides dorei. B. dorei adheres to gut cells and inhibits C. difficile multiplication. Furthermore, we have developed novel multilayer and three-dimensional gut models containing gut myofibroblasts. C. difficile adheres more efficiently to epithelial cells in these models compared to the monolayer systems, inducing a stronger chemokine response, indicating a role for myofibroblasts in early host responses to C. difficile. Our study describes new human gut models which effectively recreate the C. difficile infection process, and enable host-anaerobe and pathogen-commensal interaction studies in vitro.

sec.title: IMPORTANCE
sec.p: Understanding the host responses to anaerobic gut pathogens or commensals, and gaining mechanistic insights into the three-way interaction between pathogens, commensals and the gut epithelium is fundamental to advancing our knowledge of gut microbiome function. Host-pathogen interaction studies of the human anaerobic pathogen, C. difficile and other gut-associated anaerobes is challenging due to the lack of appropriate in vitro systems. In this study, employing novel two and threedimensional models, we have tracked C. difficile infection over longer time scales, examining the attachment and invasion of the gut epithelium and the effects of key virulence factors. Furthermore, we demonstrate interactions of other important gut commensals like Bacteroides with the epithelium and with C. difficile. This study provides new insight into the molecular and cellular events that occur at the gut epithelial interface during infection.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Clostridium difficile, an anaerobic spore-forming bacterium is the main cause of infectious diarrhea in healthcare settings. A major risk factor for C. difficile infection (CDI) is antibiotic use, which results in the disruption of the intestinal microbiota, allowing C. difficile to colonize and proliferate (1, 2). An increase in severe disease and deaths from CDI has been observed in the US, estimated at 453,000 cases, with 29,000 deaths (3). Estimates of about 13,000 cases were recorded in the UK and incidence of CDI have been reported across Europe, Canada and Australia (4–6).

C. difficile produces two main toxins, toxin A and toxin B (TcdA and TcdB), and some strains produce a binary toxin (CDT), all of which contribute to bacterial pathogenicity. Toxins A and B are known to disrupt the intestinal epithelial barrier function through activation of the MAPK pathway leading to a cytokine response (7, 8). The key role for toxins during infection has been demonstrated in mouse models using toxin mutants (7, 9). However, C. difficile colonization of the intestinal mucosa is a key factor in CDI, and several bacterial factors such as surface layer proteins (10, 11), adhesins (12–14), cell wall proteins (15) and flagella are thought to play a role in this process (16, 17). Moreover, C. difficile is also known to produce spores that are resistant to antibiotics and disinfectants (18, 19). These spores may serve as reservoir for recurrence of infection in the host.

Although animal models of CDI have been used to understand C. difficile pathogenesis, molecular mechanisms of bacterial interactions with the human gut mucosa are best studied using in vitro human colon derived cell cultures. In vitro models enable molecular and cellular studies on both the host and the pathogen, easier testing of multiple conditions and visualization of infection dynamics. Infection of human intestinal epithelial cell (IEC) lines has been used to study C. difficile pathogenesis but these models have been limited to short time periods as C. difficile requires an anaerobic environment for optimal growth (20–22). A dual environment system such as a vertical diffusion chamber (VDC), which permits growth of the bacteria and IECs in appropriate gaseous environments was used previously by Schüller and Phillips to demonstrate increased adherence of enterohaemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) to polarized IECs in microaerobic conditions, with enhanced expression and translocation of EHEC type III secreted effector proteins (23). Similarly, an increase in Campylobacter jejuni invasion of IECs was observed under a microaerobic environment in the VDC (24). Recently, a VDC was employed to culture C. difficile with T84 cells where an anaerobic environment was shown to enhance C. difficile-induced cytokine production, although this was only studied over a short time course (25).

Models that replicate the physiology and local tissue environment found in vivo are ideal for investigating host-pathogen interactions in IECs. Three-dimensional (3-D) gut cellular models are more suited for epithelial cell growth and differentiation through secretion of proteins such as growth factors by the underlying cells, and supporting scaffolds can be designed to meet the cell type-specific needs (26, 27). Scaffolds generated from natural or synthetic polymers such as matrigel, collagen and polyethylene terephthalate (PET) have been used to generate the matrix (27, 28). More recently, electrospinning has been employed to fabricate fibers from polymers creating a structure similar to the natural fibrous network of the extracellular matrix (ECM) (26, 27). Electrospinning was used to create nanofiber and microfiber scaffolds for optimal 3D in vitro culture of airway epithelial and fibroblast cells (26). Fibroblast cells play an active role in producing ECM, and producing chemokines in response to bacterial infection (29).

Three-dimensional gut models have been employed to understand key bacterial and host pathways in a range of pathogens including C. difficile (30, 31), Salmonella (32), Cryptosporidium parvum (33) and Coxsackievirus B (34). In human intestinal organoids infected with C. difficile, bacteria were reported to be viable for up to 12h (31), while a 3D model using Caco-2 cells grown as cysts in a matrigel monitored the adhesion and translocation of C. difficile for 1h (30). While both studies investigated the role of C. difficile toxins in these models, neither was able to follow the infection for a longer period of time due to the lack of an optimal environment for bacterial growth.

In this study, we have determined the infection dynamics of C. difficile over an extended time frame using novel human gut epithelium models. We demonstrate that C. difficile adheres and forms communities over 24h, while it produces spores, toxins and bacterial filamentous forms, accompanied by chemokine production over 48h in a monolayer VDC model. Furthermore, we demonstrate that this system can be used to study interactions of obligate anaerobes such as the gut commensal, Bacteroides dorei, with IECs. Interestingly, we demonstrate that B. dorei inhibits C. difficile replication on gut epithelial cells. Notably, in a complex 3-D model that we developed which contains myofibroblasts on electrospun nanofiber scaffolds, we observed increased bacterial adhesion to IECs and an enhanced host cell response, compared to the monolayer model.

sec.title: Development of a gut cellular model for C. difficile
sec.p: A polarized cell layer comprising IECs (epithelial Caco-2 and mucus producing HT29-MTX goblet cells) was cultured on the apical side of a Snapwell insert as shown in Fig. 1. Inserts with polarized cell layers were placed in the VDC and experiments were performed by perfusing a mixture of 5% CO2 and 95% air in the basolateral compartment for epithelial cell growth and an anaerobic gas mixture (10% CO2, 80% N2 and 10% H2) on the apical side for bacterial growth. The barrier integrity of IECs was monitored by measuring the transepithelial electrical resistance (TEER). The TEER values demonstrated an intact epithelium in the control IECs incubated within the VDC, although a slight decline was observed over 24h (Fig. 2A). However, no significant disruption to the IECs was seen after 24h or 48h by microscopy; actin staining showed that the cytoskeleton of the control cells was intact at 24h and 48h (Fig. 2B). Immunofluorescent staining of the Snapwell inserts for MUC2, a major mucus protein produced by goblet cells, showed that a small amount of mucus was produced (Fig. S1).

caption.title: Scheme for generation of epithelial layers for use within vertical diffusion chambers.
caption.p: For the 2-D model, intestinal epithelial cells were grown to form a polarized confluent monolayer in a Snapwell filter for 2 weeks before inserting in the VDCs. C. difficile was added to the apical chamber which is perfused with an anaerobic gas mix and incubated for different times while maintaining anaerobic conditions. The basolateral compartment was perfused with a mixture of 5% CO2 and 95% air, necessary for growth of IECs.

sec.p: Furthermore, growth of C. difficile in the apical compartment of the VDC for 3h was compared to growth in the anaerobic cabinet. No significant differences were observed indicating that the VDC maintained anaerobic conditions in the apical chamber (Fig. S2).

sec.title: C. difficile colonization leads to disruption of the intestinal epithelium
sec.p: To determine how C. difficile interacts with the human host in the short and long term, Caco-2/HT29-MTX layers were infected with C. difficile R20291 at an MOI of 100:1 for different periods of time in the anaerobic chamber of the VDC (Fig. 1). In order to study bacteria that adhere to the IECs and their replication, for all experiments, at 3h p.i., the apical supernatant containing the C. difficile was removed, the IECs washed in PBS, fresh pre-reduced media added, followed by incubation for the required time. The number of adherent C. difficile was determined by counting colony forming units (CFUs) from the cell lysates, after washing off non-adherent bacteria. A significant increase in the number of cell-associated C. difficile was observed from 3h to 24h p.i. (Fig. 2C). This increase in cell-associated bacteria corresponded to a decrease in TEER measurements indicating disruption of the intestinal epithelial barrier (Fig. 2A). Confocal microscopy showed C. difficile present as small micro-communities on the IECs. At early time points (3h and 6h p.i.), there was little disruption of the actin filaments but at 24h and 48h p.i., destruction of the cytoskeleton was evident (Fig. 2D). Interestingly, at 48h p.i., immunofluorescent staining showed the presence of filamenting C. difficile (Fig. 2D).

sec.title: Prolonged infection is associated with spore and toxin production, and host responses
sec.p: In order to fully understand bacterial factors necessary for CDI persistence, we performed an extended infection for up to 48h in the 2-D monolayer epithelial model. Spores, a major bacterial mechanism of persistence, were detected in the cell-associated fraction and in the apical supernatants at 24h and 48h p.i. (Fig. 3A).

caption.title: Production of C. difficile spores, toxins and host responses to infection.
caption.p: (A) Colony counts of spores recovered after heat treatment of the adherent C. difficile fraction and the apical supernatants in the 2-D epithelial model (B) ELISA for C. difficile toxin A shows increased toxin after extended infection (C). ELISA for human IL-8 indicates increased IL-8 production at 24h and 48h p.i.

sec.p: Toxin A was monitored over time during infection and while not detectable at early time points, increased production was seen at 24h and 48h p.i. as determined by ELISA (Fig. 3B). Analysis of the basolateral supernatant for the host chemokine IL-8, which has been previously implicated in C. difficile infection (35), revealed that IL-8 levels were low at 6h p.i. but increased at 24h and 48h p.i. in the monolayer epithelial model (Fig. 3C).

sec.title: Major C. difficile toxins are not solely responsible for disruption of the epithelial barrier
sec.p: As the toxins are considered to be the major virulence factors in CDI, we sought to determine their effects on the epithelial cells. To do this, we utilized a triple toxin mutant (ΔABCDTa) strain, which is unable to produce toxins A, B and the binary toxin (subunit CdtA) (36) to perform adhesion assays on the gut epithelium. The absence of all three toxins did not affect the adhesion of C. difficile to the IECs (Fig. 4A). As C. difficile toxins are known to cause disruption to the tight junctions of the epithelium, leading to a more permeable epithelial barrier, we measured the TEER to determine the effects of the triple toxin mutant on the IECs. At 6h p.i., there was less disruption compared to the wild type (WT) but at 24h p.i., there was no significant difference between the WT and the triple mutant (Fig. 4B). Immunofluorescent staining indicated less redistribution of the actin cytoskeleton at 24h p.i. compared to the WT strain (Fig. 4C).

caption.title: C. difficile toxins are not required for adherence to gut epithelial cells
caption.p: (A) Colony counts from epithelial cells infected with the WT R20291 and triple toxin mutant (A- B- CDTa-) demonstrates that absence of the toxins does not affect adherence to theIECs (ns, not significant) (B) TEER values showing reduction at 24h p.i. between the WT and the triple toxin mutant. (C) Representative confocal microscopy images of IECs infected with the triple toxin mutant at 24h p.i. showing less redistribution of actin, stained with phalloidin (red) as compared to the WT. Inset shows the orthogonal XZ axis view of the IECs. C. difficile is stained green, actin, red and cell nuclei, blue, Scale bar = 10 μM.

sec.title: Co-culturing C. difficile with Bacteroides dorei results in C. difficile inhibition within an epithelial gut model
sec.p: To determine if our VDC-based cellular system could be extended for use with other anaerobic bacteria, we studied a strict commensal anaerobe, B. dorei within the monolayer epithelial model using similar conditions as for C. difficile. Adherence to the IECs was determined at 3h and 24h by CFU counts, as described for C. difficile. B. dorei adhered to the epithelial cells and multiplied over 24h, as observed for C. difficile (Fig. 5A, B). B. dorei and C. difficile were then grown as mixed cultures in the VDC. Cell-associated bacteria were quantitated by plating on a medium used to selectively isolate C. difficile colonies, which also allowed the growth of B. dorei. Bacteroides colonies were distinguished by colony size, color and morphology (small colonies). A significant decrease in the number of C. difficile was observed when co-cultured with B. dorei in the presence of IECs at 24h p.i. but not at 3h p.i. (Fig. 5A, B, p < 0.001). We also observed higher colony counts when B. dorei was grown in co-culture with C. difficile at 3h and 24h, compared to mono-cultures of B. dorei (Fig. 5A, B).

caption.title: Studying C. difficile-commensal interactions within epithelial models.
caption.p: (A) Co-culture studies of B. dorei with C. difficile in the VDC showed no significant inhibition at 3h p.i. (B) However, at 24h, a significant inhibition of C. difficile is observed. Coculture Bd and Cd represents the growth of B. dorei and C. difficile respectively in the mixed culture (Bd, B. dorei and Cd, C. difficile). ***p < 0.001.

sec.title: Increased cell-associated bacteria in multilayer and 3-D models containing fibroblast cells
sec.p: As the monolayer 2-D models do not optimally represent the human gut epithelium, we developed this system further by increasing its cell complexity. Typically, a myofibroblast layer underlies the basement membrane in the human gut. To incorporate myofibroblasts into our model, human CCD-18co myofibroblasts were first grown on the basolateral side of the polyester Snapwell insert before seeding the IECs on the apical side (multilayer model, Fig. 6A). Furthermore, to recreate the highly porous architecture of the ECM in the basement membrane, epithelial and fibroblasts cells were grown apically and basolaterally respectively on inserts containing electrospun nanofiber scaffolds generated from polyethylene terephthalate to develop a 3-D gut epithelium as reported previously (26). Scanning electron microscopy revealed that these scaffolds exhibited a uniform nanofibrous matrix (Fig. 6B) that supported the attachment and proliferation of Caco-2 cells to form a confluent monolayer (Fig. 6C) and enabled the proliferation of the CCD-18co cells (Fig. 6D).

caption.title: Scheme for generation of multilayer and 3-D models containing fibroblast cells and cell growth on the electrospun nanofibrous matrix
caption.p: (A) Fibroblast cells were first seeded on the basolateral side of the Snapwell or nanofiber scaffold for the multilayer and 3-D models for 5 days. Thereafter, IECs were cultured on the apical side for 2 weeks before placing the Snapwell filter between two halves of the chamber. C. difficile was infected apically while maintaining anaerobic conditions and the basolateral compartment was perfused with 5% CO2 and 95% air. (B) Polyethylene terephthalate (PET; 10% w/v) was electrospun and exhibited a uniform nanofibrous matrix as determined by scanning electron microscopy. (C) Caco-2 epithelial cells were able to form a confluent monolayer on the nanofibrous scaffolds (the scaffold can be seen underneath the cells following processing for SEM). (D) The CCD-18co cells proliferated across the nanofibrous scaffold forming cell processes to adhere to the nanofibers.

sec.p: Interestingly, in the multilayer model, we find that after infection for 3h and 24h, higher numbers of bacteria adhered to the IECs at both time points compared to the monolayer model without fibroblasts (Fig. 7A). Anti-fibronectin staining of the basolateral side of the membrane containing the fibroblast cells indicated likely degradation of fibronectin and damage to the fibroblast layer at 24h p.i. (Fig. 7B). As before, immunofluorescent staining showed the localisation of C. difficile on the epithelial cells at 3h and 24h p.i. (Fig. 7C).

sec.p: Similar to the multilayer model, we observed increased adhesion of C. difficile to the IECs at 3h and 24h p.i. in the 3-D gut epithelium (Fig. 7D). Similarly, anti-fibronectin staining showed the impaired fibroblast layer in the 3-D model (Fig. 7E). Confocal microscopy revealed the presence of numerous C. difficile colonies on the IECs at 24h p.i. (Fig. 7F). Interestingly, at 24h p.i., immunofluorescent staining showed the presence of filamenting C. difficile (Fig. 7F), much earlier than seen in the monolayer infection model.

sec.title: A stronger chemokine response to C. difficile in the presence of fibroblasts
sec.p: In both the multilayer and the 3-D models of infection, spores were found to adhere to the epithelium and were present in higher numbers in the apical supernatant, at levels comparable to the 2-D monolayer model (Fig 8A, B). Although there was higher variability, levels of toxin A in the apical supernatants from both models were slightly lower and showed distinct toxin production profiles compared with the 2-D models. Furthermore, we measured levels of toxin B in the 3-D model and were even lower than that observed for toxin A (Figure 8C). Notably, higher levels of IL-8 were stimulated by C. difficile infection from the 3-D model (Figure 8D), suggesting a potential role for the myofibroblasts in modulating the C. difficile response.

caption.title: C. difficile spores and toxin production, and host response to infection in the multilayer and 3-D models.
caption.p: Colony counts of spores in the cell-associated C. difficile fraction and the apical supernatants in the (A) multilayer and (B) 3-D model. (C) Toxin A and B levels in the multilayer and 3-D model. (D) IL-8 levels are significantly increased in the 3-D model at 24h p.i., **p < 0.01 as determined by the student t test.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: Attachment to the intestinal mucosa and subsequent multiplication and penetration of the gut epithelium by a pathogen is generally essential for the establishment of a successful infection. We report here the development of in vitro human gut models for studying interactions of obligate anaerobes with the host gut epithelium. For the first time, we have modeled prolonged C. difficile infection in an in vitro human gut mimic. Along with demonstrating C. difficile micro-communities, we report formation of C. difficile filaments, a potential adaptation mechanism during infection.

Previous in vitro infection models have shown the attachment of C. difficile on IECs either using conditions that are not appropriate for the bacterium (such as growing in aerobic conditions) or that are limited to short term infection due to the anaerobic growth requirements of C. difficile (21, 25, 37). However, in order to study host-pathogen interactions at a molecular and cellular level, precise environmental control and longer scales of infection are essential. The monolayer gut epithelial model described here is ideal for investigating molecular mechanisms underlying C. difficile-epithelial interactions as it offers the ability to make cellular, immunological and molecular measurements along with easy substitution of knockout cell lines and introduction of additional cellular components like immune cells.

Filamentation, a process where bacterial cells continue to elongate without division, is caused in response to environmental or host stress as a way of adaptation and survival (38). For example, uropathogenic E. coli in bladder epithelial cells subvert innate immune responses by forming filaments, which evade being phagocytosed by neutrophils (39). Our findings indicate that C. difficile filamentation may serve as a mechanism of persistence in the human host. Filamentation may be associated with host cell contact and infection, as preliminary studies indicate that incubation in similar conditions in the absence of cells does not appear to induce this phenotype. Previous studies demonstrated that Burkholderia pseudomallei forms filaments when exposed to B-lactam antibiotics to evade killing by the antibiotics (40). Similarly, in E. coli, an SOS response occurs when exposed to β-lactams or fluoroquinolones leading to the formation of multinucleated filaments (41). It may be that in vivo, C. difficile form filaments to avoid being killed by antibiotics but more studies are needed to confirm this and the mechanisms underlying C. difficile filament formation.

Production of spores was observed at 24h and 48h p.i. indicating that spore formation is a key feature of C. difficile infection of the gut epithelium, as reported previously using mouse models (42). Previous work showed that C. difficile spores adhere to undifferentiated Caco-2 cells after 1h of infection as determined by viable spore counts and fluorescence microscopy (37). Interestingly, we detected similar numbers of spores in the cell-associated bacterial fraction and in the apical supernatants in both the epithelial monolayer and the multilayer/3-D models, suggesting that a high number of the spores formed adhere to the epithelium. This may further indicate that adhesion of spores to the gut mucosa is an inherent feature of C. difficile infection.

Toxin production by C. difficile is known to play a role in pathogenesis by disrupting the barrier integrity of the intestinal epithelium leading to increased permeability and reorganization of actin (8). Previous work showed that there was no significant difference in adherence of C. difficile (strains R20291 and 630) and their respective toxin mutants (tcdA and tcdB) to the IECs (25). Our data indicate that a strain lacking the major toxins A, B and the binary toxin also does not differ in cell adhesion. Strikingly, the absence of all toxins did not abrogate the increased permeability of the epithelium seen during infection. While there appeared to be a slower decrease in permeability for the triple toxin mutant, ΔABCDTa (Fig. 4B), epithelial integrity was reduced to a level comparable to the WT by 24h p.i. These data suggest that in addition to the main toxins, secreted enzymes or other factors produced by C. difficile and bacterial adhesion per se via cell surface proteins to the host cells, may contribute to bacterial invasion of the gut epithelium. Further studies on C. difficile surface factors and secreted proteins in a toxin negative strain background are required to clarify this.

The human gut microbiota is dominated by the Firmicutes and Bacteroidetes, which are known to play a role in health and disease (43, 44). As >90% of the bacteria inhabiting the gut are obligate anaerobes, little is known about the adhesion properties of individual bacteria to the intestinal epithelium. Previous research on Bacteroides fragilis, a dominant bacterium isolated from intestinal tract infections showed that bile salts enhance the adhesion to the intestinal epithelium and biofilm formation (45). However, for other dominant members of the Bacteroidetes phylum, there is insufficient data as to how they interact with the gut epithelium. Our studies with B. dorei, a common gut anaerobe in healthy individuals, demonstrates bacterial adhesion and multiplication on IECs, and validates the utility of this in vitro model in studying host cell interactions of other anaerobic gut bacteria.

While the gut microbiota is known to protect against C. difficile infection (2), the direct interactions between commensals and gut pathogens have been poorly understood. Although many genome sequencing studies have associated members of the Bacteroidetes with healthy status, the roles of individual Bacteroides species in the gut remains unclear (46–48). Recently, it was shown that Bacteroides ovatus inhibited C. difficile growth in the presence of bile acids (49). In this study we demonstrate suppression of gut cell-associated C. difficile by B. dorei, in the absence of bile acids and in a physiologically relevant setting. In addition to host-pathogen interactions, the models developed in this work allow three-way interaction studies between commensals, pathogens and the host, i.e. the role of commensals in modulating effects of pathogenic bacteria on the human host. Additionally, as these results may also suggest the potential of non-spore forming anaerobic bacteria in suppressing C. difficile growth, such in vitro tools may have value in screening and developing novel microbial therapies for treatment of C. difficile and other anaerobic infections.

Three-dimensional models are known to promote more in vivo-like cell proliferation, growth differentiation and cell-to cell contact (27). Nanofiber scaffolds, which create a porous architecture similar to the basement membrane underlying the gut epithelium, along with myofibroblast cells in the basal layer, form an excellent mimic of the intestinal epithelium. Morris et al showed that nanofibers were beneficial for epithelial cell differentiation but not penetrable to fibroblasts (26). In addition to producing an ECM which provides structural and biochemical support to cells, fibroblasts are also known to produce chemokines when activated by infectious microorganisms such as bacteria (29). Thus, the increased amount of the chemokine IL-8 observed in the 3-D model could be attributed to the myofibroblasts, also as the presence of myofibroblasts is the only difference between the multilayer/3-D models and the monolayer model. Thus, the myofibroblasts may be important in responding to C. difficile infection. In addition, the increased C. difficile adhesion observed in the multilayer and the 3-D models, which presumably leads to quicker progressing infection, could also be the result of indirect modulation of the epithelial barrier by the myofibroblast cells. Both the multilayer and 3D gut models have huge potential in studying C. difficile pathogenesis, particularly for investigating host invasion and interactions with basolateral surface of the host epithelium and are currently being utilized for studying functions of secreted C. difficile factors in the laboratory.

Overall, we have developed highly useful tools for studying C. difficile host-interactions which we expect to have broad applications in studying anaerobic gut commensals and their interactions with pathogens and the host.

sec.title: Bacterial strains used and growth conditions
sec.p: C. difficile R20291 was cultured on brain heart infusion agar (Sigma-Aldrich, UK) supplemented with 1 g/L cysteine (Sigma-Aldrich, UK), 5 g/L yeast extract (BHIS) under anaerobic conditions (80% N2, 10% CO2, 10% H2) in a Don Whitley workstation (Yorkshire, UK). The triple toxin mutant, R20291 tcdA tcdB cdtA (A-B-CDTa-), a kind gift from Sarah Kuehne and Nigel Minton (36) was cultured in the same media as the WT strain supplemented with lincomycin hydrochloride (Sigma-Aldrich, UK).

sec.title: Cell culture
sec.p: Intestinal epithelial cell line, Caco-2 (P6-P21) from American Type Culture Collection, mucus producing cell line, HT29-MTX (P45-P56), gift from Nathalie Juge and fibroblast cells, CCD-18co (P10-P17) were used. Caco-2 cells were grown in Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle Medium (DMEM) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1% penicillin-streptomycin. HT29-MTX was grown in DMEM and CCD-18co in Eagle’s Minimum Essential Medium media. Both media were supplemented with 10% FBS, 1% penicillin-streptomycin, 2 mM glutamine and 1% non-essential amino acids (Sigma-Aldrich, UK). All cell lines were maintained in 5% CO2 in a humidified incubator at 37°C.

For the epithelial 2-D models, Caco-2 and HT29-MTX were mixed in a 9:1 ratio and 2 × 105 cells/mL were seeded on a 12 mm Snapwell inserts (tissue culture treated polyester membrane, Corning, New York, USA) supported by a detachable ring for 2 weeks to form a polarized monolayer. For the multilayer and 3-D models, CCD-18co (1 ×104 cells/ml) were first seeded on the basolateral layer of the polyester Snapwell insert or electrospun nanofiber scaffold for 5 days after which Caco-2 and HT29-MTX were seeded on the apical side as in the 2-D models for 14 days. Prior to the infection experiments, the cell culture medium in the Snapwell inserts was replaced with antibiotic-free medium.

sec.title: Vertical diffusion chamber set up and measurement of transepithelial electrical resistance
sec.p: The Snapwell inserts containing the polarized cell layer were placed between the two half chambers of the vertical diffusion chamber (Harvard Apparatus, Cambridge, UK) and sealed with the provided clamps. DMEM with 10% FBS was placed on both sides of the chamber. Transepithelial electrical resistance measurements was performed using Harvard/Navicyte electrodes on the EC-800 Epithelial Voltage Clamp (Harvard Apparatus, Cambridge, UK) over 24h.

sec.title: Infection of intestinal epithelial cells (IECs)
sec.p: A single bacterial colony was inoculated in pre-reduced BHI broth (Oxoid) supplemented with 1 g/L cysteine (Sigma-Aldrich, UK) and 5 g/L yeast extract and incubated at 37 °C overnight. The culture was centrifuged at 10,000g for 5 mins (Eppendorf 5810R) and bacterial pellet was resuspended in DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS and incubated at 37 °C for at least an hour. This culture was used to infect the IECs at a predetermined MOI of 100:1 in the apical side of the VDC containing the IECs. The apical chamber was diffused with anaerobic gas mixture (10% CO2, 10% H2, 80% N2, BOC, UK) and the basolateral compartment with 5% CO2 and 95% air (BOC, UK). At 3h p.i., the apical media containing the C. difficile was removed, the IECs washed in PBS and prereduced DMEM with 10% FBS added. It was incubated for a further 3h or up to 24h. The apical and basolateral media was then removed and stored at −80 °C. The IECs were washed thrice in PBS before lysing in sterile water. Serial dilutions were performed and plated on appropriate plates to determine the number of cell-associated bacteria. To determine spore production, the lysed cells and apical supernatants were heat treated at 65°C for 20 mins, serial dilututed and plated on BHI agar supplemented with 0.1% sodium taurocholate (Sigma-Aldrich, UK).

For the co-culture experiments with B. dorei, the same protocol was followed except that both strains were grown in Schaedler anaerobic broth (Oxoid, UK) overnight and an MOI of 1000: 1 was used. To differentiate C. difficile colonies from B. dorei, the BHIS agar was supplemented with C. difficile selective supplement (Oxoid, UK).

sec.title: ELISA assays
sec.p: C. difficile toxin production was determined by ELISA following the manufacturer’s instructions (tgcBIOMICS, Bingen am Rhein, Germany). IL-8 production was also determined by analysis of basolateral supertants from VDC’s using a human IL-8 ELISA kit (R&D systems, Minneapolis, USA).

sec.title: Electrospinning protocol
sec.p: Electrospinning procedure was performed as described previously (26). Briefly, scaffolds were produced by dissolving polyethylene terephthalate (PET, from food grade drinking bottles) in equal ratio of trifluoroacetic acid and dichloromethane (1:1) to create a 10% (w/v) PET solution to produce the nanofiber scaffolds. Electrospinning processing parameters included an applied voltage of 14kV, a tip-collector distance (TCD) of 15cm, a flow rate of 0.5 mL/h and an 18 gauge spinneret for a period of 2h. Electrospinning was conducted at ambient conditions in a ducted fume hood with fibers collected on a stainless steel rotating drum (50 rpm). Once collected, the scaffolds were stored in aluminum foil at room temperature until required. Prior to cell culture, scaffolds were positioned in 12 mm Snapwell inserts (Corning, New York, USA) by replacing the commercial membrane with the electrospun nanofiber matrix. PET scaffolds were cut into 2.5 cm diameter circles and fixed with Costar Snapwell inserts using aquarium sealant glue (King British, Beaphar Company). They were sterilized by exposing to UV at the power of 80 mJ/cm2 for 15 minutes on each side using a UV lamp (CL-1000 Ultraviolet Crosslinker) and soaking in 10x antibiotic-antimycotic solution (final concentration: 1,000 units/mL penicillin, 1 mg/mL streptomycin and 2.5 μg/mL amphotericin B, Sigma Aldrich, Poole, UK) for 3h at 25 °C. Antibiotic-antimycotic solution was then removed and the scaffolds were washed with PBS (pH 7.4) three times. The scaffolds were air-dried in the microbiological class 2 safety cabinet overnight.

sec.title: Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM)
sec.p: The fiber morphology of the nanofiber scaffolds was assessed using SEM. Acellular samples were sputter coated (Leica EMSCD005) with gold for 4-5 mins prior to microscopy. Scaffolds seeded with cells were fixed in 3% (v/v) glutaraldehyde overnight at 4°C. Samples were washed thrice in PBS and dehydrated through a series of industrial methylated spirits (IMS) concentrations diluted in water (25-100% v/v) for 10 mins each. Following dehydration, hexamethyldisilazane (HMDS) was added to chemically dry the samples, this process was then repeated and the samples allowed to air dry overnight before sputter coating as described above. Scaffold and cell morphology was observed at various magnifications as indicated on the scale bar of the images (JEOL JSM-6100, JEOL, UK). Images were processed using ImageJ software (W. Rasband, National Institute of Health, USA) to determine the fiber diameter and 150 measurements (50 measurements per scaffold) from 3 independently produced scaffolds were assessed.

sec.title: Immunofluorescence and imaging
sec.p: The Snapwell inserts, containing either the commercial membrane or PET nanofiber scaffold, were fixed in 4% PFA for 15 min, washed in PBS, permeabilized with 1% saponin (Sigma-Aldrich, UK) in 0.3% triton X-100 (Fisher Scientific, UK) and thereafter blocked against non-specific antibody binding with 3% BSA in PBS (Sigma-Aldrich, UK). For staining C. difficile, infected cells were incubated with anti-C. difficile serum for 1h, followed by Alexa Fluor 488 goat anti-rabbit secondary antibody (New England Biolabs, UK) for 1h. Alexa fluor phalloidin 647 was used to stain the actin cytoskeleton and cell nuclei were stained with ProLong Gold Antifade mountant containing 4,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI) (New England Biolabs, UK). To determine mucus production, the Snapwell inserts were fixed, permeabilized and blocked as described above. The Snapwell insert was incubated with mucin 2 anti-rabbit primary antibody (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, US) overnight at 4°C followed by Alexa Fluor 488 goat anti-rabbit secondary antibody (New England Biolabs, UK) for 1h. Images were taken using a confocal spinning-disk microscope (VOX UltraView, PerkinElmer, UK) with a 40X oil objective and two Hamamatsu ORCA-R2 cameras, by Volocity 6.0 (PerkinElmer, UK). Post-image analysis was performed with ImageJ software.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Student t test (two tailed) was used to determine the significance between two groups. Significance is represented as *p < 0.05, **p < 0.01, ***p < 0.001 and ****p < 0.0001. Except stated otherwise, all the results presented are the average of 3 independent experiments performed in duplicates or triplicates. The error bars indicate the standard deviation (SD).
